awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Bioeconomic Analysis for Arctic Marine Resource Governance and Policy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 14-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum. The Belmont Forum is a high level group of the world?s major and emerging funders of global environmental change research and international science councils.  It aims to accelerate delivery of the international environmental research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. Each partner country provides funding for their researchers within a consortium to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders.  This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions.

Working together in this Collaborative Research Action, the partner agencies have provided support for research projects that utilize existing Arctic observing systems, datasets and models to evaluate key sustainability challenges and opportunities in the Arctic region, to innovate new sustainability science theory and approaches to these challenges and opportunities, and support decision-making towards a sustainable Arctic environment.  This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and end users (e.g., policy makers, regulators, NGOs, communities and industry).  

The efforts of the Bioeconomic Analysis for Arctic Marine Resource Governance and Policy (BAAMRGP) collaborative research team will address the need for integrated, cross-sectoral ecosystem-based ocean management in the Arctic through the valuation and optimization of Arctic marine resources across multiple levels of governance.  The approach will consider not only fisheries and subsistence species, but species with indirect or non-use implications, overall biodiversity and productivity, as well as the relationship between the marine ecosystem and humans, including health, commerce, and management.  The researchers from the US, Iceland, Russia, Greenland, Canada, Denmark, Norway, and New Zealand will leverage existing data sets and expertise in game theory, bioeconomic valuation and modeling, and fisheries assessment to develop game models in cooperation with a variety of stakeholders, including indigenous peoples of the north.  The effort will also consider different scenarios introduced by amendments to existing conventions under the Polar Code.  A PhD student will receive training in interdisciplinary science and gain international research experience during the course of this project.

por.por_cntn:
Bio-Economic Analysis for Arctic Marine Resource Governance and Policy, BAAMRGP

 

Invasive species are considered an important driver of biodiversity loss.

This project addresses determinants of economic and ecological changes in Arctic marine resources as a result of the way commercially valued invasive species are managed.  The Red King Crab (Paralithodes camtschaticus) and Snow Crab (Chionoecetes opilio) invasions in the Barents Sea provide ideal cases for the project that has broader implications.

  • We combine concepts from economics, ecology, fishery biology, etc to address bioeconomic trade-offs associated with invasive species management. Understanding the economic incentives, the different stakeholders' interests, and the underlying trade-offs behind biological invasions is central to optimal management and efficient allocation of resources.
  • We analyze policies and decision-making processes at the intersection between conservation of Arctic marine ecosystems and socioeconomic welfare of fishing communities. Our approach reappraises the role of commercial harvesting as a management tool for controlling invasive species. The lack of knowledge and scientific consensus about features of the invasion does not reduce the need to act on little information. Such cooperation may be particularly difficult in light of imperfect information about the net benefits of prevention of invasive species. Those benefits are also unequally distributed according to bio-economic conditions.
  • The uncertain costs of the invasive crabs (or the benefits from removing it) have been an important barrier in addressing management. We addressed the challenge by applying economic insights to patterns of research investments and their implications for policy decisions and investments in marine environmental quality. Specifically, we now better understand: (1) biases in primary research agendas across Russia and Norway linked to economic expectations, and how vertical and horizontal integration in knowledge production and management can either foster or prevent sub-optimal downstream outcomes, and (2) how incentives for allocating research funds at the invasion frontier may deepen these biases. When insufficient comparability and concerns about bias prevented direct meta-analysis of ecological costs, we instead empirically investigated the disparities in the literature and management decisions across vested interests to uncover how economic incentives systematically vary across research investments.
  • A snapshot of our research questions & our findings:
  • In exploring the fundamental trade-off between ecological consequences and financial benefits of the profitable red king crab invasion, we developed an interest in understanding how different stakeholder interests & economic incentives: a) Feed into research agendas within ecology b) Supplement an inconclusive biological & ecological literature, c) Affect resource management. We found that scientific research agendas shifted over time in response to changes in relative trade-offs.
  •  Is it a poor management of the commercial crab stock, a poor knowledge of the ecosystem values lost or a poor knowledge of the natural resources at stake from the invasion? The findings highlight the importance of the prioritizing criterion in research resource allocation.
  • Low harvesting costs, uncertain ecosystem losses and ongoing infrastructure investment in onshore landing facilities all shape Norwegian stakeholders' interests in favor of a long-term management of the fishery.
  • Understanding the bioeconomic trade-off is therefore fundamental for providing insights into Norway’s management. Further, species invasions comprise social costs, and as such may call for regulatory interventions across political and national boundaries that require incentive-compatible cooperation. Cooperation can be particularly difficult in light of imperfect information about the net benefits of preventing those invasions which may be distributed unequally according to bio-economic conditions. We therefore analyzed management cooperation between Russia and Norway, that share the crab stock, to identify trade-offs and gains from cooperation caused by the crab’s dispersal.
  • The snow crab is another case of a lucrative invasion for which Norwegians and Russians develop different harvest control strategies on their own continental shelves. Here we have a similar problem of an invasion on a frontier that has had open access over the first years of its introduction. The closure of the open access has facilitated spread of the invasion. It is well established in the fisheries economic literature that closing the commons enhances profits. In order to bring awareness to important dimensions of commons management that the literature has missed, we argue that the details of ecological processes matter in determining net benefits, and in doing that we highlight the importance of examining the problem within a holistic framework that encompasses ecological, economic, legal and climatic aspects of the problem.
  • We have communicated our research through peer reviewed publications, conference presentations, provided graduate and undergraduate transdisciplinary training, stakeholder network channels through UArctic and PICES, have provided reports and interaction with working groups of the Arctic Council (AMAP, CAFF, Sustainable Development) and venues such as Arctic Experts Meeting for advising Icelandic Chair of Arctic Council –Under Harvard’s Arctic Initiative.
